Record date: 2090-10-09
NAME: Usrey, John
MRN: 6762675
This is a 76-year-old man who comes in with a chief complaint of left calf pain.
This occurs after walking about one block and pain is sufficient to prevent him
from walking further. He will then stop, pain will disappear. He will continue
walking at which time it will occur at about the same distance. There is no rest
pain. The pain had been present for a couple of months although it has been
increasing in severity.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Is significant for intracranial bleed secondary to an
AV malformation. He refused surgery at that time at Campellton-Graceville Hospital and has done
well on Dilantin without any seizures. There has been no further bleed or problem
from this malformation. He also has treated hypothyroidism. He is status post
TURP, cholecystectomy, and appendectomy. He does have a chronic anxiety
disorder for which he is on Ativan intermittently. He also has pustular psoriasis.
MEDICATIONS: Dilantin 600 mg per day, which keeps his level at about 7. At
these levels he has had no seizures. He is also on Synthroid at 0.075 per day.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: He is a mostly German-speaking man. There is a
right-sided tremor which has been present since his intracranial bleed. Neck
supple. Blood pressure is at 140/80. Weight 184. Heart rate is at 70. There are
no carotid bruits. Lungs are clear. Heart is regular without gallop or murmur.
Abdominal exam - No mass, tenderness, or organomegaly. There are multiple
scars. There is a bruit over the right femoral artery with a decreased pulsation there
compared to the left. There is no pulse palpable below popliteal on the right side.
There is no visible ischemic change of the right leg. The left femoral is fuller, and
there is a palpable dorsalis pedis on that side.
IMPRESSION: Peripheral vascular disease, probably right iliofemoral. He will
undergo arteriovascular studies. He will also be placed on aspirin at 81 mg per
day. In addition he is begun on Lipitor 10 mg per day for hyperlipidemia. He will
follow up following that vascular study. This evaluation was also communicated to
her daughter, Quinn, because of the language barrier.
Xenia Jaramillo, M.D.
